text: 40 City Record. COURTS.     DISTRICT COURT—Lake County. Meets at Court House on the first Monday in April, first Monday in January, and the first Monday in August. Jasper D. Ward, Judge; C. W. Tay- lor, Clerk.  COUNTY COURT—Meets at Court House on the first Mon- days in the months of January, March, May, July, September and November, <A. T. Gunnell, Judge; William Raymond, Clerk.  CRIMINAL COURT—Lake County. Mceta at the Court Tiouse on the first Mondays in March, June, September and December. A. W. Rucker, Judge; J. L. Bartow, Clerk.  POLICE COURT—Meets daily from 9 until 12 o’clock at City Jail, 210 South Pine. Samuel McDowall, Judge.  BANKS.     FIRST NATIONAL BANK—F. A. Raynolds, President; Nelson Hallock, Vice President; S. N. Dwight, Cashier; Charles B. McVay, Assistant Cashier. 100 East Chestnut, cor- ner EHarrison avenue.  MERCHANTS AND MECHANICS BANK-—L. M. Smith, President; L. J. Smith, Cashier. Warrison avenue, southeast corner Third.  MINERS EXCITANGE BANK—James H. B, MecFerran, President ; George W. Trimble, Cashier ; A. V. Ilunter, Acting Cashier. 130 west Chestnut.  THE BANK OF LEADVILLE—Horace A. W. Tabor, Presi- dent; George R. Fisher, Cashier. Jocated on Chestnut street, southwest corner Harrison avenue.  THE CITY BANK—C. C. Howell, President ; James Streeter, Vice President; S. M. Strickler, Assistant Cashier. Located 110 Eaat Fifth.

label: 1882 City Directory
text: wil  INTRODUCTORY.  Orrick oF THE CITY Preserowset  Junx, 1882.  This our third annual volume of the Leadville City Directory we believe will be found even more useful than its predecessors, in consequence of the more settled and permanent condition of our citizens. The information haa been collected in the most careful manner by thoroughly competent persons, and we have spared neither labor or expense to make it accurate and usefal to the public, as well as creditable to the city.  We feel that we have reason to congratulate our citizens upon the continued prosperity in our business circles, as well as the permanency of our great mining interests, which were never in & more flourishing and prosperous condition than at present: Building has assumed a more substantial character, and during the present year many new buildings will be erected that will be both serviceable and ornamental.  Hoping this volume will meet the approbation of the public generally, and prove to our business men that it is worthy of a more general and substantial patronage, we take this opportunity to express our sincere thanks to those who have extended their favors to sustain us in the publication of a work so convenient and indispensable. Cc. & B.

label: 1885 City Directory
text: INTRODUCTORY.  OrFicre oF THE Ciry Directory, JuLy, 1885.  Six years have elapsed since the issue of the first volume of the Leadville City Directory, during which time we have faith- fully chronicled, from year to year, the growth and prosperity of the most enterprising city on the continent.  Since our last issue, Leadville has undergone a decided change for the better—she has recovered from a financial crisis and the evil consequences of an unprecedented boom. Confidence in the permanency of our mining and commercial interests is estab- lished, and many who left in despair after the “boom,” are returning better satisfied than ever that there is no place like © Leadville; and we are confident there are more people residing here at present, with a view to permanency, than in any previous  ear. .  y Persons experienced in mining are satisfied that there are as good bodies of mineral, undiscovered, in the immediate vicinity of Leadville and Lake County, as ever have been touched by the pick and shovel of the miner. In view of these few simple facts, we feel justified in predicting for the great ‘‘ Carbonate Camp,” in the near future, a larger bullion yield than ever before.  Very few, if any, of those who find the Directory so useful, have any conception of the arduous task of collecting and arrang- ing the matter intelligibly, and the amount of labor and constant care required to produce such a work—one from which the citi-  'zer or stranger, by referring to its pages, can readily find infor- mation of importance connected with the city.  We wish to impress an important fact upon the minds of those consulting the Directory for information which they do not readily find, that all names are arranged in strict alphabetical order according to the manner in which they are spelled, and not as they are pronounced, therefore one should know the correct spelling of the name to be able to find it easily.  We return our sincere thanks to the merchants and citizens of the “Cloud City ” for the patronage and courtesies extended to us on this work, and again'renew our promise to make each succeeding issue of the City Directory more worthy of commen- dation and patronage.  C. & 3B.

label: 1881 City Directory
text: INTRODUCTORY,  Orrice of THE Crrr Pamneron}  June, 1881.  ‘The continued popularity of Leadville as the most prosperous bullion producing section of the Rocky Mountains, together with her importance as a commercial centre, demands a better and higher degree of completeness in all her local institutions. Recognizing the justice of thia sentiment the publishers of this work, since its inanguration one year ago, have labored earnestly to increase its usefulness, and render it, as they trust they have, an indispensable item in every business ‘house and public office in Leadville.  The labor, care and expense which has been so generally bestowed on the volume now about to be dismissed on its mission, we are confident will satisfy all, of the earnestness and sincerity of our purpose, and demonstrates that the City Directory of Leadville, in all departments, stands in the front rank of its class, and it shall always be our aim to make it 2 complete mirror of the mining, commercial and professional interests of Leadville, producing in the briefest form a history of Leadville’a progress from year to year.  We congratulate our citizens upon the prosperous condition of the mines and the substantial prosperity so plainly visible in all branches of trade, and to our patrons, the enterprising and public spirited inhabitants of Leadville, we return our sincere and hearty thanks. . Cc &B.
